Award.AwardTitle: Physics-Based Study of Graphene Colloidal Systems as Metal Working Fluids for Micro-Machining Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to test the hypothesis that the four key graphene platelet design factors, namely, (1) platelet shape and size; (2) number of graphene layers within a platelet; (3) interfacial surface chemistry between graphene and the dispersion medium; and (4) graphene concentration, all influence the lubrication and cooling efficiency of graphene-enhanced metal working fluids. This objective will be achieved by four major research tasks, namely, (1) manufacture of engineered graphene platelets and property characterization of their colloidal dispersions; (2) micro-turning experiments to study the effect of graphene platelet design factors on the performance of the metal working fluid; (3) characterization of the impact dynamics and evaporation of the graphene-laden micro-droplets; and (4) engineering the graphene platelets for use in environmentally benign algae oil-based cutting fluids.

If successful, this research will result in the improvement of the lubrication and cooling performance of a wide variety of metal working fluids used by the manufacturing industry in the United States. This is a multi-billion dollar market that affects the cost of products used in key areas including defense, aerospace, health care and consumer electronics. It will also advance sustainable manufacturing initatives by providing the knowledge needed to design graphene-based additives for use in high-performance environmentally-benign cutting fluids. The outreach activities pursued as part of this research will encourage both the New York state high school students as well as the Navajo minority students in New Mexico, to pursue higher education in the fields of science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The research findings of this project have shown that graphene-enhanced semi-synthetic metal working fluids (MWFs) significantly outperform conventional MWFs in terms of their lubrication and cooling efficiency. The ultrasonically-exfoliated graphene platelets (with 2-3 graphene layers and lowest in-solution characteristic lateral length of 120 nm) appear to be the most favorable for micromachining applications. Even at the lowest concentration of 0.1 wt%, they are capable of providing a 51% reduction in the cutting temperature and a 25% reduction in the surface roughness value over that of the baseline semi-synthetic cutting fluid. For the thermally-reduced graphene platelets (with 4-8 graphene layers and in-solution characteristic lateral length of 562 -2780 nm), a concentration of 0.2 wt% appears to be optimal. The results reveal that the most important criterion dictating the machining performance of these colloidal solutions is their ability to form uniform, sub-micron thick films of graphene, upon evaporation of the carrier fluid. In addition to semi-synthetic MWFs, the benefits of adding graphene platelets are also seen to carry over to high-performance environmentally benign cutting fluids such as canola oil. 

The use of carbon-rich, graphene oxide colloidal suspensions has also been shown to address the tool wear issue encountered during diamond-turning of steel. Machining tests conducted on a low-carbon steel alloy reveal that the use of graphene oxide colloidal suspensions result in a ~74% reduction in the tool wear over that seen under dry machining conditions. It also results in a ~50% reduction in the cutting temperatures and a ~20-30% reduction in the cutting forces, when compared against the dry machining condition. The trends seen in the cutting temperatures, cutting forces and the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data collectively point to the possibility of the graphene oxide platelets serving as a barrier to the carbon diffusion reaction. This barrier mechanism has also been confirmed using molecular dynamics simulations.

 

Broader Impact

The findings of this research will enable improvements in the lubrication and cooling performance of a wide variety of metal working fluids used by the manufacturing industry. This is a multi-billion dollar market that affects the cost of products manufactured for use in key societal areas including defense, aerospace, health care and consumer electronics. The work also has implications for the upcoming industry involving the harvesting of algae oil, as it could likely result in the development of high-performance environmentally benign bio-oils. The tool-wear reduction obtained by using carbon-rich, graphene oxide colloidal suspensions has the potential to make diamond a cost-effective tool material to machine steels. 

On the educational front, the research findings have been integrated into multiple graduate and undergraduate manufacturing courses at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, NY. An interactive, Lego-based outreach module was also designed to introduce micro/nano-manufacturing concepts to middle-school students in the upstate New York area. In terms of human resource development, this project provided opportunities for the training and development of student researchers (3 PhD and 6 undergraduate) in the areas of advanced manufacturing and nanomaterial synthesis. One of the PhD students supported by this grant now serves as the co-founder of EnerMat Technologies Inc., a New York-based company that focuses on energy applications of graphene.
